article.title: Partial correlation analysis method in ultra-relativistic heavy-ion collisions

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the second term in the formula for partial covariance c(X,Y|Z) represent?
choices: The covariance between X and Y.
The variance of the control variable Z.
The component of covariance between X and Y due to their correlation with Z.
The conditional covariance between X and Y given Z.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the variable η represent in the context of the superposition approach?
choices: Transverse momentum of a hadron.
Space-time rapidity of a fluid cell.
Temperature of the fluid cell.
Azimuthal angle of a hadron.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the superposition approach, what is the significance of the subtraction term δAA\' W(m) in the formula for scaled covariance of sources?
choices: It accounts for the detector acceptance.
It removes the autocorrelations of particles produced from the same source.
It represents the correlation between different sources.
It incorporates the effects of resonance decays.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the BT model with the sum of left and right peripheral bins as control, what does the term U₁U₂ represent in the formula for partial C-correlation of source multiplicities?
choices: Variance of the number of wounded quarks in nucleus A.
Product of normalized rapidity coordinates of the forward and backward bins.
Average number of sources at the central rapidity bin.
Scaled variance of the total number of wounded quarks.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between the two panels in Figure 1, which show the two-particle C-correlation in pseudorapidity?
choices: Panel (a) includes autocorrelations, while panel (b) removes them.
Panel (a) represents primordial particles, while panel (b) represents all charged particles.
Panel (a) includes the effects of resonance decays, while panel (b) only considers primordial particles.
Panel (a) uses a wider centrality bin compared to panel (b).

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the close agreement between the BT model and the simulated data in Figure 2?
choices: The superposition approach is not valid for analyzing these correlations.
The partial correlation technique can successfully isolate initial state correlations after removing the effects of resonance decays.
The wounded quark model is not suitable for describing the initial state in this collision system.
The bin mixing effect is negligible in this analysis.

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the depletion along the lines η₁= 0 and η₂= 0 in Figure 3(a)?
choices: It is a genuine physical effect reflecting the correlations between particles.
It is an artifact of the central reference bin placement and the definition of partial C-correlation.
It arises due to the short-range correlations from resonance decays.
It is a consequence of the limited acceptance window used in the simulation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main limitation of using the partial p-correlation compared to the partial C-correlation?
choices: It is more sensitive to statistical fluctuations.
It cannot be used with a central reference bin.
It does not provide information about the scaled variance.
It is only applicable to primordial particles.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the results shown in Figure 6, where the partial C-correlation function is evaluated with two peripheral reference bins?
choices: This configuration is not suitable for studying initial state correlations.
The BT model prediction of vanishing partial correlation in this configuration is consistent with the simulated data.
This approach is highly sensitive to the short-range correlations from resonance decays.
The use of two peripheral bins significantly amplifies the effects of centrality fluctuations.
